terms.definition: A genus of fungi (yeasts) naturally found on human skin. In Seborrheic Dermatitis, these yeasts proliferate excessively by feeding on sebum and producing irritating substances.
A protective 'slimy' layer produced by microorganisms (like Malassezia) to protect themselves from antifungal treatments and the immune system.
Fundamental components of fats and oils. Specific fatty acids (chain length C11-C24) feed Malassezia and must be avoided.
The outer layer of the skin that retains moisture and protects against external agents. In SD, the barrier is often compromised, causing inflammation.
Chemical compounds formed by the reaction between a fatty acid and an alcohol. Many 'heavy' esters (e.g., Isopropyl Palmitate) are food for Malassezia.
A chemical process where water breaks molecular bonds. Malassezia uses enzymes (lipases) to hydrolyze sebum triglycerides and release irritating free fatty acids.
General term for fats, oils, and waxes. Not all lipids are harmful to SD: squalane and MCT oil are 'safe' lipids.
International Nomenclature of Cosmetic Ingredients. It is the standardized list of ingredients found on the back of cosmetic products.
Oily substance produced by the sebaceous glands of the skin. It is the natural food for Malassezia.
Medium Chain Triglycerides (C8 and C10). A special oil that Malassezia CANNOT metabolize, making it the only safe oil to moisturize skin with SD.
A stable hydrocarbon derived (often) from olives or sugarcane. It is chemically identical to part of human sebum but does not feed the fungus.
Measure of acidity. Healthy scalp has pH 5.5. A higher pH (>6.0) promotes Malassezia growth.
Enzymes produced by Malassezia to 'digest' fats (sebum or cosmetic products) and transform them into nourishment.
Accelerated detachment of dead skin cells, visible as 'dandruff'. It is an inflammatory response to the presence of irritating free fatty acids.
Common emulsifiers (e.g., Polysorbate-20, -80) that contain fatty acids. Often used in medications, but can feed Malassezia if not balanced.
Ingredients derived from microbial fermentation (e.g., Galactomyces). Very popular in K-Beauty, but risky for SD because they often contain nutrient residues for yeasts.
A protein 'sensor' in skin cells. When activated by Malassezia byproducts, it triggers a massive inflammatory response (Th17 pathway), causing redness and itching.
Small signaling proteins (like IL-17, IL-6) released by the immune system. In SD, a 'cytokine storm' causes the visible inflammation and accelerated skin cell turnover.
The primary cells of the epidermis (90%). In SD, they are attacked by Malassezia metabolites and respond by releasing inflammatory signals and shedding too quickly (dandruff).
The community of microorganisms (bacteria, fungi, viruses) living on the skin. SD is a state of 'dysbiosis' where Malassezia dominates the scalp microbiome.
An imbalance in the microbial community. In SD, diversity decreases and Malassezia fungi take over, displacing beneficial bacteria.
Sugars found in cell walls of fungi (like Malassezia and Galactomyces). The immune system recognizes them as 'threats', triggering immediate inflammation.
The specific arm of the immune system responsible for fighting fungal infections. It is chronically overactive in SD, leading to persistent inflammation even when the fungus is reduced.
The number of carbon atoms in a fatty acid molecule. This is the #1 factor in SD safety. C11-C24 feeds the fungus; C8-C10 is safe.
Refers to chemical bonds in fats. Unsaturated fats (liquid oils like Olive) have double bonds that oxidize easily. Saturated fats (solid butters) are stable but can still be food for fungus.
The process where oils 'go rancid' on the skin due to Malassezia activity or UV light. These oxidized lipids are toxic and cause itching.
Unstable molecules (free radicals) released during inflammation. They damage skin cells and barrier proteins, worsening the cycle of SD.
Hydrophilic loves water; Lipophilic loves oil. Malassezia is 'lipophilic' (fat-loving), which is why it thrives in oil-rich areas like the scalp and face.
Cleansing agents. Harsh ones (SLS) strip all oils, destroying the barrier. Gentle ones (Glucosides) clean without damaging the skin's protection.
Ingredients like EDTA that bind minerals. They can destabilize the cell walls of fungi (good) but also disrupt the skin barrier (bad) if concentration is too high.
Ingredients that attract water (Glycerin, Hyaluronic Acid). Essential for SD because the barrier is damaged, but must be used without oils that trap heat.
Ingredients that form a seal (Petrolatum, Silicones). In SD, they can be dangerous because they trap sweat and heat, creating a greenhouse for fungus.
Detailed description of ingredients that soften skin. In SD, use safe emollients like Squalane or MCT, not vegetable oils.
A C18 monounsaturated fatty acid found in Olive Oil and Sebum. It is a major trigger that breaches the skin barrier and triggers inflammation.
A C12 fatty acid (50% of Coconut Oil). It is the most explosive fuel for Malassezia. Must be strictly avoided.
Lipids that act as the 'mortar' between skin cells. SD skin is deficient in Ceramides, making barrier repair crucial.
A mix of amino acids and salts produced by healthy skin to hold water. SD skin often produces defective NMF.
A sugar molecule that holds 1000x its weight in water. A safe, oil-free hydration hero for Seborrheic Dermatitis.
A common antifungal agent. It works by starving the fungus of iron and increasing zinc levels, which inhibits growth.
A broad-spectrum antifungal medication. It disrupts the fungal cell membrane synthesis. The gold standard for SD treatment.
A BHA (Beta Hydroxy Acid) that exfoliates dead skin and penetrates oil ducts to dissolve sebum buildup.
The rate at which water evaporates from skin. In SD, the barrier is broken, so TEWL is high, leading to 'oily but dehydrated' skin.
The protective acidic film (pH 4.5-5.5) on skin surface. Malassezia hates acid; alkalinizing products (soap) destroy this mantle and invite infection.
Means 'does not clog pores'. Crucial for SD because clogged pores trap sebum, creating a feeding ground for yeast.
Formulated to minimize allergy risk. Important because SD skin is 'leaky' and reacts more strongly to allergens like fragrance.
An acute outbreak of symptoms (redness, itch, flaking). Usually triggered by stress, diet, weather, or incorrect products.
A period where symptoms disappear. This is the goal. It is not a 'cure', but a controlled state maintained by a safe routine.
Applying a product to a small area (behind ear) for 24-48h to check for reactions before full use. Essential for sensitive SD skin.
